text:
GLOSSARY
Following is a brief glossary of technical terms used in the broadcast lecture
series:
All ITERATION: The repetition of the initial letter or sound in two or more
closely associated words or stressed syllables. Example: "She moan of
doves in tasaamorial elms, and murmuring of innumerable bees."—Tennyson.
GHAUT: A kind of song in which words are intoned to a monotonous musical background*
Chants are less melodious than songs, and are instead characterized by the
repetition of a few simple musical phrases.
CSp^UIALISM: An expression used in spoken rather than written language. It
may differ from formal language in pronunciation, grammar, vocabulary.
Imagery or connotative quality, and may eventually become part of standard
usage*
CCOTOTATION: The implication that words or phrases carry with them, what a word
suggests as distinguished from its specific meaning (Denotation).
CONSONANCE: Qfce repetition of a consonant pattern as in "hall” and "fill", in
the t middle or at the end of words.
DIALECT: The language of a particular area or group of speakers as distinguished
from the standard language.
DENOTATION: The limited and specific definition of a word or phrase as distinguished
from its larger meaning—in which connotation is involved.
ECHOIC WORDS: Words which imitate a sound in nature. Examples: splash, hiss,
crack, sizzle.
END-STOPPED LISES: lines of poetry in which the end of the lines coincide with
a normal speech pause.
FOOT: The metrical unit of peotry, a combination of one accented and one or more
unaccented syllables* The most frequently used foot in English poetry is the
iambic foot.
FEMININE ENDING:
